headline.main: CANDIDATES MAP TV BARRAGE IN 2 KEY STATES

results.snippet: With just about every turn of the television dial these days in Iowa and New Hampshire, viewers are encountering the image of a Democrat who wants to be President.    Click. Former Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida approaches down a country road, his...
results.lead_paragraph: With just about every turn of the television dial these days in Iowa and New Hampshire, viewers are encountering the image of a Democrat who wants to be President. Click. Former Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida approaches down a country road, his station wagon enveloped in a boil of dust and the lonesome chords of an unseen harmonica. Click. Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale appears first as the hand and then the man, reeling in a fishing line from a country pond. ''I'm sort of a farm kid,'' he confides.

headline.main: DEMOCRATS, IN FOREIGN POLICY DEBATE, URGE BEIRUT WITHDRAWAL

results.snippet: Seven Democratic candidates for President coalesced around their opposition to the continued presence of United States marines in Lebanon tonight in a debate at Harvard University.    Former Senator George McGovern, noting that 259 marines have...
results.lead_paragraph: Seven Democratic candidates for President coalesced around their opposition to the continued presence of United States marines in Lebanon tonight in a debate at Harvard University. Former Senator George McGovern, noting that 259 marines have been killed in Lebanon, said he wondered ''how long some people are going to have to wait'' before withdrawing them. ''We should stop worrying about saving face and start worrying about saving lives,'' Mr. McGovern said during the debate on foreign policy at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government. It was sponsored by the school's Institute of Politics and the Boston Globe.

headline.main: COUNTDOWN GOES SMOOTHLY FOR LAUNCHING TODAY OF 8-DAY SHUTTLE MISSION

results.snippet: The space shuttle Challenger is set to begin an eight-day mission Friday that will include critical tests of the abilities of spacewalking astronauts to repair orbiting satellites.   Five astronauts, six laboratory rats and a 15-ton cargo,...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Challenger is set to begin an eight-day mission Friday that will include critical tests of the abilities of spacewalking astronauts to repair orbiting satellites. Five astronauts, six laboratory rats and a 15-ton cargo, including two communications satellites, are scheduled for launching at 8 A. M. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reported today that countdown preparations for the 10th shuttle flight were the smoothest ever, almost without flaw. A clear sky and cool temperatures were forecast for liftoff time. The Challenger is to climb to an orbit of 190 miles, where it will deploy two communications satellites on the first two days of the flight. The first is Westar 6 for Western Union Corporation. The second is Palapa B-2 for the Indonesian Government.

headline.main: AT THE MOVIES

results.snippet: 'Quartet' star explores film's many strings.     ''BASILEUS QUARTET,'' which has been playing at Lincoln Plaza I for the last month, opens today in California, and a lot of other states. So one of its stars, the 28-year-old Pierre Malet, has come...
results.lead_paragraph: 'Quartet' star explores film's many strings. ''BASILEUS QUARTET,'' which has been playing at Lincoln Plaza I for the last month, opens today in California, and a lot of other states. So one of its stars, the 28-year-old Pierre Malet, has come to the United States to take a look around. He thinks it's a nice place to visit, but he wouldn't want to live here. ''It's a too- big country for me,'' he says. ''It's six hours flying if you want to go to Los Angeles from New York. In France, everything is human distance, for human beings.''

headline.main: SKETCHES OF CHALLENGER'S CREW OF 5

results.snippet: Vance Devoe Brand   The mission commander and an old hand at orbiting in space . . . United States command module pilot on Apollo spacecraft when it hooked up with the Soviet Union's Soyuz in 1975 . . . He and two crewmates narrowly escaped serious...
results.lead_paragraph: Vance Devoe Brand The mission commander and an old hand at orbiting in space . . . United States command module pilot on Apollo spacecraft when it hooked up with the Soviet Union's Soyuz in 1975 . . . He and two crewmates narrowly escaped serious injury when toxic jet thruster gases leaked into the cabin on Apollo's return to earth . . . In 1982 he commanded the Columbia on the fifth space shuttle flight, the first fully operational shuttle mission . . . Supervised deployment of two communications satellites placed in geosynchronous orbit on that flight . . . Born 52 years ago in Longmont, Colo., in shadow of the Rocky Mountains, the son of a veterinarin . . . Majored in business administration in college, but decided to go into aviation and earned master's degree in aeronautical engineering . . . Test pilot for Lockheed before being picked as an astronaut in 1966 . . . Blonde, gray- eyed, 5 feet 11 inches tall . . . Married to the former Beverly Ann Whitnel . . . Has five children. Robert Lee Gibson The pilot of the mission was born into a family of fliers and is married to an astronaut . . . Commander in the Navy . . . Born Oct. 30, 1946, in Cooperstown, N.Y. . . . His father, Paul A. Gibson, served as a military aviator and his mother held a pilot's license . . . Regarded as outspoken and witty by his peers, who nicknamed him Hoot, after the actor Hoot Gibson . . . Guided by his parents, he was at the controls of the family plane at the age of 10 . . . Earned a private pilot's license at 17 . . . Graduated from high school in Huntington, L.I., and earned a degree in aeronautical engineering at California Polytechnical State University . . . Considers Lakewood, Calif., his hometown . . . Entered Navy flight training upon graduation from college in 1969 . . . Flew 56 combat missions in Vietnam . . . Has chalked up 3,000 hours flying 35 different types of aircraft . . . Joined NASA in 1978 . . . For relaxation, he flies an acrobatic racer and radio-controlled model planes . . . married in 1981 to the former Margaret Rhea Seddon, a physician and astronaut . . . they have two children.

headline.main: SATELLITE IT CARRIED APPEARS LOST

results.snippet: Five astronauts rode the space shuttle Challenger into orbit today and deployed a communication satellite that later appeared to be lost in space.   The satellite, owned by Western Union Corporation, was reported late tonight to be out of contact...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Five astronauts rode the space shuttle Challenger into orbit today and deployed a communication satellite that later appeared to be lost in space. The satellite, owned by Western Union Corporation, was reported late tonight to be out of contact with the shuttle or any ground tracking stations. The North American Aerospace Command at Colorado Springs was searching the skies for the satellite. It was not clear whether the satellite's rocket ever fired to boost it toward its higher orbit.

headline.main: SHUTTLE HAS SECOND MAJOR MISHAP AS A BURST BALLOON CANCELS TESTS

results.snippet: A target balloon released from the space shuttle Challenger today burst into shreds, forcing the astronauts to curtail a critical rehearsal of rendezvous maneuvers for making repair calls on orbiting satellites.   It was the second serious mishap...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A target balloon released from the space shuttle Challenger today burst into shreds, forcing the astronauts to curtail a critical rehearsal of rendezvous maneuvers for making repair calls on orbiting satellites. It was the second serious mishap to strike this mission, which had already suffered a malfunction that sent a communications satellite into the wrong orbit Friday after what had seemed a flawless launching from the shuttle's cargo bay. Engineers reported today that they had found the satellite and it appeared to be in good shape, but probably would never be usable as a communications relay because it is out of position. Westar Cannot Be Retrieved The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said that although the shuttle was designed to retrieve and repair satellites, the Westar was not built with the grappling fixtures necessary for retrieval because it was supposed go into orbit far out of the shuttle's reach. The satellite malfunction initially forced a one-day delay in the launching of a second communications satellite, the Palapa B-2.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS POISED FOR BOLD WALK

results.snippet: Despite the accidents that have beset the mission so far, the Challenger astronauts were ready to go ahead with plans Tuesday morning for their most daring venture, jet-powered excursions outside in orbit and free of any link to the spaceship.   ...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Despite the accidents that have beset the mission so far, the Challenger astronauts were ready to go ahead with plans Tuesday morning for their most daring venture, jet-powered excursions outside in orbit and free of any link to the spaceship. It will be one more moment in the space age when science fiction comes true. Never before have spacewalking astronauts been without a safety line or been able to move about under jet power. This will be a dress rehearsal for the shuttle mission in April to attempt to repair an ailing scientific satellite.

headline.main: FEMALE ASTRONAUTS VIE FOR FIRST SPACE FLIGHT

results.snippet: IF a movie about male astronauts is attracting a good deal    of attention these days, can   anybody doubt that a movie about female astronauts won't be far behind? And, more likely than not, on television? Tonight, then, at 9 o'clock, CBS is...
results.lead_paragraph: IF a movie about male astronauts is attracting a good deal of attention these days, can anybody doubt that a movie about female astronauts won't be far behind? And, more likely than not, on television? Tonight, then, at 9 o'clock, CBS is offering the female equivalent of ''The Right Stuff'' under the title of ''The Sky's No Limit.'' Furthermore, with a script by Renee and Harry Longstreet, it's a pretty good flick. This wholly fictional account is set in 1980, when the United States had yet to send a woman into space even though the Soviet Union has already done just that twice. Indeed, among the National Aviation and Space Administration's 58 astronauts in training, eight are women. With preparations being made for the first flight of the Challenger shuttle, the press and the public are pressing NASA officials for a decision about recruiting a woman for the crew. In this version of things, three women are priority candidates. Being the first woman in space has its own special importance. As one candidate observes, ''I don't remember the guy who followed Columbus, do you?''

headline.main: 2 ASTRONAUTS FLOAT FREE IN SPACE, 170 MILES UP

results.snippet: In a spectacle of bravery and beauty, two American astronauts flew out, up and away from the space shuttle Challenger today. Free of any lifeline and propelled into the dark void by tiny jets, they became, in effect, the first human satellites.  ...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: In a spectacle of bravery and beauty, two American astronauts flew out, up and away from the space shuttle Challenger today. Free of any lifeline and propelled into the dark void by tiny jets, they became, in effect, the first human satellites. The successful test of the propulsion backpacks - a wireless high-wire act 170 miles above the earth - was an important step toward future operations to repair and service orbiting satellites and to assemble and maintain large space stations. A second test by the same two space fliers, Capt. Bruce McCandless 2d of the Navy and Lieut. Col. Robert L. Stewart of the Army, is scheduled for Thursday morning. They are to practice grappling a large object rotating at the end of the shuttle's mechanical arm, a dress rehearsal for a mission in April to repair a crippled scientific satellite.

headline.main: GLENN CAMPAIGN IS SEEKING TO STRESS HIS POLITICAL EXPERIENCE

results.snippet: In the last several days Senator John Glenn has been talking about such things as economic assumptions, the real growth in gross national product, ''cooked numbers'' and ''budget baselines.''    In his effort to make an impressive showing against...
results.lead_paragraph: In the last several days Senator John Glenn has been talking about such things as economic assumptions, the real growth in gross national product, ''cooked numbers'' and ''budget baselines.'' In his effort to make an impressive showing against seven other candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination in the New Hampshire primary on Feb. 28, the Ohio Senator has been speaking in the argot of a small circle of Washington budget experts. His message is that the economic plans of Walter F. Mondale, the leading Democratic candidate, would provide the nation with deficits bigger than President Reagan's. With the primary only three weeks away, Senator Glenn is continuing his attempt to portray the former Vice President as an excessive spender and the instrument of such special interests as organized labor. But the real motivation behind this increased talk of the national budget appears to be as much an attempt to define Mr. Glenn as it is an effort to define Mr. Mondale.

headline.main: HOLLINGS ASSERTS MONDALE CAN'T WIN WHITE HOUSE

results.snippet: Senator Ernest F. Hollings has been telling Democratic gatherings in the South and New England that Walter F. Mondale might get the party's nomination for President but that he would be defeated by Ronald Reagan in November.    Mr. Hollings makes...
results.lead_paragraph: Senator Ernest F. Hollings has been telling Democratic gatherings in the South and New England that Walter F. Mondale might get the party's nomination for President but that he would be defeated by Ronald Reagan in November. Mr. Hollings makes this assertion after scolding Mr. Mondale for being, in his view, so beholden to interest groups, such as labor, that he will fail to attract enough Democratic voters in the general election. While Mr. Hollings admits, as he did today to a group of reporters here, that he is only ''an asterisk'' in the national polls, he insists his ''centrist'' views would enable the Democrats to regain the White House. ''We don't want the interest groups to rob us of our party,'' the Senator from South Carolina said late Wednesday in an interview in his office in the Capitol. ''And that's what's been happening. And I think that in New Hampshire that they don't want the interest groups to be robbing us of our party.''

headline.main: SPIRITS ARE HIGH IN 2D SPACE WALK

results.snippet: Two free-flying astronauts joked and turned somersaults in space today and then practiced docking to a satellite berthed in the shuttle Challenger's cargo bay.    But a problem with the shuttle's mechanical arm kept them from fully rehearsing the...
results.lead_paragraph: Two free-flying astronauts joked and turned somersaults in space today and then practiced docking to a satellite berthed in the shuttle Challenger's cargo bay. But a problem with the shuttle's mechanical arm kept them from fully rehearsing the techniques they plan to use for a satellite repair mission in April. An arthritic wrist on a robotic arm prevented them from attempting to latch onto the satellite as it was to have hung out in space, slowly rotating, from the mechanical arm. Despite the loss of this test, space officials said they were satisfied with the equipment and with the rehearsal, in which the astronauts used jet-powered backpacks to maneuver in space.

headline.main: TOWARD WOMEN, MOVIES ARE TWO-FACED

results.snippet: T een-angel or succubus? Virgin or whore? Should we continue to put the blame on Mame, boys, and is it true that the devil is a woman?  You might think that after more than half a century, moviemakers - and the people who go to movies - would have...
results.lead_paragraph: T een-angel or succubus? Virgin or whore? Should we continue to put the blame on Mame, boys, and is it true that the devil is a woman? You might think that after more than half a century, moviemakers - and the people who go to movies - would have become bored by these somewhat less than probing questions, especially since there are now more films that take women seriously than we've had at any time in years, but not at all. The age-old male fantasy about woman's sexual duplicity appears to have endured unscathed into the age of Women's Liberation. Women may well be making their presences felt more than ever before in business, government, science and the arts, and even as characters in other movies, but there are still producers catering to the delirious male suspicion that within every innocent young thing there exists the soul of a wanton.

headline.main: DEMOCRATIC RIVALS JAB AT MONDALE IN DEBATE

results.snippet: The eight major Democratic Presidential candidates met here today in a debate marked by polite but persistent criticism of Walter F. Mondale, who has a strong lead in the polls in his bid for party's nomination.    As campaign strategists had...

byline.original: By HOWELL RAINES, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The eight major Democratic Presidential candidates met here today in a debate marked by polite but persistent criticism of Walter F. Mondale, who has a strong lead in the polls in his bid for party's nomination. As campaign strategists had predicted, the attacks on Mr. Mondale were the major feature of the second nationally televised debate of the campaign year. But the two-and-one-half-hour program at the Des Moines Civic Center nine days before Iowa's precinct caucuses failed to generate the heated emotion of the year's first major debate in Hanover, N.H., last month. Like that debate, this one was marked by strong criticism of Presdent Reagan's domestic and foreign policy. The most sharply worded condemnation came from Senator John Glenn of Ohio, who accused Mr. Reagan of following a ''morally bankrupt'' policy in Lebanon.

headline.main: GLENN DOESN'T BELIEVE IN LEAVING THEM LAUGHING

results.snippet: As the Iowa precinct caucuses draw near and Senator John Glenn faces his first real test of 1984, his top campaign officials are recalling one of his first outings in the arena of Presidential politics. It happened last spring, at the...
results.lead_paragraph: As the Iowa precinct caucuses draw near and Senator John Glenn faces his first real test of 1984, his top campaign officials are recalling one of his first outings in the arena of Presidential politics. It happened last spring, at the Massachusetts State Convention. Many of the other Presidential contenders had applied makeup for the television cameras. Mr. Glenn's staff, telling him he needed a little tone in his face, urged him to use some as well. ''I'm not going to go out and talk to people with makeup on my face,'' he said.

headline.main: FROM ONE LIVING ROOM IN IOWA, OPINIONS ON THE 8

results.snippet: Five couples from this farming community north of Des Moines had just finished watching the debate among eight Democratic Presidential contenders.  What they had to say was not good news for Walter F. Mondale, the former Vice President, who leads...
results.lead_paragraph: Five couples from this farming community north of Des Moines had just finished watching the debate among eight Democratic Presidential contenders. What they had to say was not good news for Walter F. Mondale, the former Vice President, who leads in the polls. ''It was very good for me,'' Gwen Wolter, an accountant at Iowa State University at Ames, said after the broadcast of the debate, held Saturday. ''I had felt sort of depressed because the polls made me feel Mondale had it sewed up. But after watching, I felt I had a choice. I came out feeling that the other fellows had a lot more to offer than I thought they had.''

headline.main: AT 25, BARBIE IS HEALTHY, WEALTHY AND CELEBRATED

results.snippet: There would seem to be no cause for undue alarm. But some time in the near future, perhaps next year, the population of Barbie Dolls will probably surpass the population of living, human Americans - those made of natural materials, us.    The...
results.lead_paragraph: There would seem to be no cause for undue alarm. But some time in the near future, perhaps next year, the population of Barbie Dolls will probably surpass the population of living, human Americans - those made of natural materials, us. The Barbie population was about 200 million and America's population - with a three-century head start - was 235,071,793 yesterday as Barbie's 25th birthday was celebrated at the American International Toy Fair in Manhattan. The fair has attracted 12,000 buyers and 850 exhibitors from 60 nations to New York this week, fair offficials said.

headline.main: 'ENDEARMENT' TOPS OSCAR NOMINATIONS

results.snippet: ''Terms of Endearment,'' a tragicomic movie about the relationship between a mother and daughter, today led the Academy Award nominations as expected, receiving 11 in nine separate categories.    The major surprises in the nominations announced by...
results.lead_paragraph: ''Terms of Endearment,'' a tragicomic movie about the relationship between a mother and daughter, today led the Academy Award nominations as expected, receiving 11 in nine separate categories. The major surprises in the nominations announced by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences included the spurning of two big-star performances and the nominating of several specialized low-budget movies - all costing less than $5 million and most less than $4 million - for two or more major awards. The low- budget films include ''Reuben, Reuben,'' ''Tender Mercies,'' ''Fanny and Alexander,'' ''Educating Rita,'' and, in particular, ''The Dresser.'' In addition to a nomination for best picture, ''The Dresser'' - which tells the story of the last days of an aging English actor and his relationship with the man who runs his backstage life - received nominations for its two leading actors, Albert Finney and Tom Courtenay; for its screenplay, and, in perhaps the day's biggest surprise, for its director, Peter Yates. ''The Dresser'' was joined in the race for best picture by ''The Big Chill,'' a comedy about seven college friends coming to terms with death and the compromises of adulthood; ''The Right Stuff,'' the story of the first seven American astronauts and the legendary test pilot who preceded them; ''Tender Mercies,'' the redemption of a country-western singer, and ''Terms of Endearment.'' The most notable omission was ''Silkwood,'' which was a runner-up for the New York Film Critics award.

headline.main: BRIEFING

results.snippet: Warming Up the Voters    Politicians, particularly those   stumping intensively for the   Presidency, have certain set anecdotes they deliver to warm up their audiences. One variety is the self-depreciating kind that still manages to convey a bit...

byline.original: By William E. Farrell and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: Warming Up the Voters Politicians, particularly those stumping intensively for the Presidency, have certain set anecdotes they deliver to warm up their audiences. One variety is the self-depreciating kind that still manages to convey a bit of ego. Senator John Glenn, the former astronaut who is one of eight Democrats seeking his party's Presidential nomination, makes use of one. He tells of an effusive introduction he got at some unspecified point in the campaign in which the master of ceremonies ''rattled off every certificate, accolade and achievement I ever had and some I never dreamed of having.'' Then, the tale goes, the introducer says, ''There are few truly great men in the world,'' and Mr. Glenn is presented. Heady stuff, the candidate says. On the way home, he says he turned to his wife, Annie, and said: ''You know, when you think about it, there really are few truly great men in this world.'' And she replies, ''There's surely one less than you think there is.'' He sometimes varies the anecdote by making the ego deflater his daughter, Lyn.

headline.main: MONDALE HAS FAMILIARITY IN HIS FAVOR

results.snippet: NEWTON, IOWA   W HEN the Democrats in this farming and industrial town of 16,000 people hold their precinct caucuses tomorrow night, Don Salisbury will almost certainly be there to vote for former Vice President Walter F. Mondale. Tyra White, who...
results.lead_paragraph: NEWTON, IOWA W HEN the Democrats in this farming and industrial town of 16,000 people hold their precinct caucuses tomorrow night, Don Salisbury will almost certainly be there to vote for former Vice President Walter F. Mondale. Tyra White, who likes Senator Gary Hart, might have to stay home with her daughter. Mr. Mondale sparks little popular enthusiasm. But his backers tend to be activists like Mr. Salisbury, a lawyer and former county chairman, who will bother to trek down to the ornate Jasper County Court House and stand up for their candidate. Senator Hart and some other long-shots have stirred interest. But many of their supporters are neophytes, such as Mrs. White, a 29-year-old housewife, who has never attended a caucus and does not know where hers is being held.

headline.main: CANDIDATES FACING FIRST MAJOR TEST IN IOWA CAUCUSES

results.snippet: When they assemble in precinct caucuses across Iowa Monday night, a comparative handful of this state's citizens will start the process in which the nation's 106 million registered voters will be called upon to choose the next President.    As...

byline.original: By HOWELL RAINES, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: When they assemble in precinct caucuses across Iowa Monday night, a comparative handful of this state's citizens will start the process in which the nation's 106 million registered voters will be called upon to choose the next President. As they have done every four years since 1972, the Iowa caucuses mark the official start of the Presidential campaign year. But the beginning of the 1984 campaign finds the Democratic and Republican parties confronted by very different political tasks in Iowa and around the nation. Different Task for G.O.P. In the coming months, Democratic voters must select a Presidential candidate from among eight major candidates who are in an increasingly bitter contest for the nomination. Republicans must rally public support for an incumbent President who is riding a crest of personal popularity at the same time that his policies are stirring opposition among many important voter groups.

headline.main: JOURNEY TO THE MOUNTAIN OF THE ARK

results.snippet: MARVINE HOWE is a reporter for The New York Times who was a correspondent in Turkey and Greece for four years.      Anyone who needs help to climb Mount Ararat should just telephone Ahmet Aga, Dogubayazit 314 (office) or 410 (home).  Ahmet Coktin,...
results.lead_paragraph: MARVINE HOWE is a reporter for The New York Times who was a correspondent in Turkey and Greece for four years. Anyone who needs help to climb Mount Ararat should just telephone Ahmet Aga, Dogubayazit 314 (office) or 410 (home). Ahmet Coktin, who is better known by the traditional Turkish title of respect, Aga, or chief, owns the deed to the southern side of the legendary mountain and believes he knows where Noah's ark can be found. It's no easy feat to climb the peak, but Ahmet Aga has enough knowledge and influence to protect mountain climbers from sheep dogs and nomads and save them from dropping into bottomless snow-covered pits. For the first time in many years, Turkish authorities have opened up Mount Ararat to foreign travelers, who must apply for the necessary permits at least three months in advance. The Mountain of Pain, or Agri Dagi, as it is known in Turkish, has been a restricted zone for at least 13 years and before that there was only limited access. The main reason given was Soviet complaints that the ark seekers were in reality spying on Soviet installations on the other side.

headline.main: DEMOCRATS' IOWA CAMPAIGN ENDS WITH SHARP ATTACKS ON MONDALE

results.snippet: On the eve of Iowa's precinct caucuses, the Democratic Presidential candidates wrapped up their campaigning in the state today to await the first judgment of voters in 1984.    The closing hours were marked by more sharp attacks on former Vice...

byline.original: By PHIL GAILEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: On the eve of Iowa's precinct caucuses, the Democratic Presidential candidates wrapped up their campaigning in the state today to await the first judgment of voters in 1984. The closing hours were marked by more sharp attacks on former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, who is leading in the public opinion polls, by some of his opponents. Mr. Mondale, who was campaigning in Florida today before returning here Monday afternoon, is expected to win the caucuses handily. The main goal of his challengers is to finish behind him in such a way as not to be written off before the nation's first Presidential primary in New Hampshire Feb. 28.

headline.main: CLOSE RACE FOR 2D AS GLENN TRAILS

results.snippet: Walter F. Mondale won a commanding victory in the Iowa Democratic caucuses today, and John Glenn, running far back in the eight-candidate field, took a beating that threatened to cripple his Presidential candidacy.    In a surprising performance...

byline.original: By HOWELL RAINES, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Walter F. Mondale won a commanding victory in the Iowa Democratic caucuses today, and John Glenn, running far back in the eight-candidate field, took a beating that threatened to cripple his Presidential candidacy. In a surprising performance based on his effective late campaigning here, Senator Gary Hart of Colorado finished second in the initial electoral test of the 1984 campaign. Not far behind Mr. Hart was former Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, whose candidacy here was initially regarded as a nostalgic curiosity. Mr. Hart hailed his showing as a breakthrough. But Mr. McGovern's unexpectedly high finish also seemed to mark something of a political resurrection for the man who was the Democrats' nominee in 1972.

headline.main: BRIEFING

results.snippet: Stand on Rights    The National Council on the Humanities, the policy-making   group of the National Endowment for the Humanities, has stepped into the developing controversy over affirmative action in Federal employment by voting overwhelmingly...

byline.original: By William E. Farrell and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: Stand on Rights The National Council on the Humanities, the policy-making group of the National Endowment for the Humanities, has stepped into the developing controversy over affirmative action in Federal employment by voting overwhelmingly that the endowment group ''should neither favor nor slight anyone because of race, color, national origin, religion or gender.'' The council thus supported the position of the chairman of the endowment, William J. Bennett, who announced last month that he would not set numerical goals for women and minority group members employed by his agency, as required by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, to avoid any ''different or special treatment'' based on sex, racial or religious distinctions. Wendell L. Willkie, general counsel of the endowment, said the vote, taken last Friday after a half-hour of debate, showed 13 council members for the resolution and 4 either against or abstaining, by an otherwise unrecorded show of hands. Only 17 of the 26 members, all appointees of President Reagan, were at the quarterly meeting.

headline.main: COULD NOT FIGHT ANY DISEASE

results.snippet: David, the 12- year-old boy who had spent almost all of his life in sterile isolation, died tonight of unknown causes, 15 days after he came out of the plastic bubble he had lived in since birth.    His doctors had hoped that a bone marrow...

byline.original: By WAYNE KING, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: David, the 12- year-old boy who had spent almost all of his life in sterile isolation, died tonight of unknown causes, 15 days after he came out of the plastic bubble he had lived in since birth. His doctors had hoped that a bone marrow transplant performed five months ago would make it possible for him to live a normal life. Early indications were that the transplant, a new technique, had worked, but David twice fell ill, recovered, then got badly sick. He died in a hospital room at 8 o'clock after treatment failed.

headline.main: DEMOCRATS EXPECT HARD SENATE FIGHT

results.snippet: After a disheartening summer and fall, Senate Democratic strategists finally received a lift when they recently persuaded former Gov. William Winter of Mississippi to declare his candidacy for the Senate seat held by Thad Cochran, a Republican...

byline.original: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: After a disheartening summer and fall, Senate Democratic strategists finally received a lift when they recently persuaded former Gov. William Winter of Mississippi to declare his candidacy for the Senate seat held by Thad Cochran, a Republican completing his first term. But the Democrats still acknowledge they face an uphill fight to regain control of the Senate. ''This is the big break we've been waiting for,'' Audrey Sheppard, assistant executive director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, said of the Winter candidacy. ''It's the best thing that's happened to us in a long time.''

headline.main: MONDALE STARTS FAST ON WHAT COULD BE A SHORT COURSE

results.snippet: CONCORD, N.H.   I N a perfect world, two mainly Republican states that   will choose only 2 percent of the 3,933 delegates to this   year's Democratic National Convention would have   little to do with naming the party's Presidential nominee. But...
results.lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. I N a perfect world, two mainly Republican states that will choose only 2 percent of the 3,933 delegates to this year's Democratic National Convention would have little to do with naming the party's Presidential nominee. But in the highly imperfect world of practical politics, Iowa and New Hampshire are demonstrating once again why they play an outsized role in the nominating process. Iowa's caucuses have been trendsetters since 1972, and since 1952 no candidate has won the Presidency without first winning his party's New Hampshire primary. This year, the fast-starting, ''frontloaded'' campaign calendar is further inflating the already exaggerated importance of these two states.

headline.main: GLENN MAINTAINS UPBEAT MOOD IN THE WAKE OF DISAPPOINTMENT

results.snippet: In his hotel room, John Glenn sits quietly, awaiting the knock on the door beckoning him to start another campaign day.    ''I'll tell you about campaigning,'' he says with a smile. ''Sharing ideas and getting views from other people is exciting,...
results.lead_paragraph: In his hotel room, John Glenn sits quietly, awaiting the knock on the door beckoning him to start another campaign day. ''I'll tell you about campaigning,'' he says with a smile. ''Sharing ideas and getting views from other people is exciting, exhilarating. But if anyone tries to tell you they enjoy the hurly-burly, the 20th event of the day, shaking 200 hands when you're dead tired, if anyone tells you that, watch out because they're lying.''
